novice.name: variables and types
novice.description: Python is completely object oriented, and not 'statically typed'. You do not need to declare variables before using them, or declare their type. Every variable in Python is an object.

novice.name: Lists
novice.description: Lists are very similar to arrays. They can contain any type of variable, and they can contain as many variables as you wish. Lists can also be iterated over in a very simple manner.

novice.name: Basic Operators
novice.description: This section explains how to use basic operators in Python.

novice.name: String Formatting
novice.description: Python uses C-style string formatting to create new, formatted strings.

novice.name: Basic String Operations
novice.description: Python is completely object oriented, and not 'statically typed'. You do not need to declare variables before using them, or declare their type. Every variable in Python is an object.

novice.name: Conditions
novice.description: Python uses boolean variables to evaluate conditions. The boolean values True and False are returned when an expression is compared or evaluated.

novice.name: Loops
novice.description: There are two types of loops in Python, for and while.

novice.name: Functions
novice.description: Functions are a convenient way to divide your code into useful blocks, allowing us to order our code, make it more readable, reuse it and save some time.

novice.name: Classes and Objects
novice.description: Objects are an encapsulation of variables and functions into a single entity. Objects get their variables and functions from classes. Classes are essentially a template to create your objects.

novice.name: Dictionaries
novice.description: A dictionary is a data type similar to arrays, but works with keys and values instead of indexes. Each value stored in a dictionary can be accessed using a key, which is any type of object (a string, a number, a list, etc.) instead of using its index to address it.
